Firearm has seen use but wood is solid (has some unusual wear on left side of butt) and in good shape other than nicks,dings and scratches as seen after 120+ years of use. The stock is dark but nicely figured and would clean up well in my opinion. Maybe a good restoration gun? NOTE on the side safety, a small percentage of Commercial Sporting Martini Rifles have the side safety which are notorius for NOT working. This one does work but I would have the gun checked by a qualified gunsmith since it is an antique. It is nice though to find a side safty that seems to work as designed! BONUS. Barrel marked, "Henry Rifling" and "Express 3 1/4 Case." The history of .450 BPE (from Wikipedia): In 19th century Britain there were a large number of straight .450 cartridges developed of varying case lengths up to the 3¼-inch version. The .450 3¼-inch Black Powder Express was developed in the 1870s and quickly became a very popular black powder sporting cartridge, manufactured in the UK, France, Germany, Austria and Canada.[1] The cartridge was readily available in both BP and Nitro for Black versions well into the 20th century,[1] and second hand rifles can still be obtained quite easily. The cartridge has survived to the current day as the .450 Nitro for Black, the same cartridge loaded with mild loadings of modern smokeless powder, carefully balanced through trial to replicate the ballistics of the Black powder version. Oval form flat-topped barrel with rear sight graduated to 1000yds.*** ***ADDITIONAL INFO ON AFRICAN EXPRESS SIGHTS: This rifle has the typical SOUTH AFRICAN "express" sights of African rifles known as "African Sights." These sights were on many sporting long arm in Southern Africa (Rhodesia, The ZAR and OVS Boer Republics, German West Africa, The Cape Colony and others) during the mid to late 19th century. They were not really for shooting game as a .577-450, .500-450 or the .303 was not usable as a 500-1000 yard hunting cartridge but it is believed by some that these sights were either unofficially required by Britain, The Boer Governments, or they simply became a standard of “fashion” with the idea being that civilians could stand and fight with the military as volunteers or as militia. The sights allowed groups of civilians to lob "volley fire" on the massed natives who generally attacked in large, noisy and well advertised groups. This African tactic of “noise and numbers” worked quite well on other natives but Europeans, Afrikaners and the English had a nasty habit of holding their ground and firing large caliber, heavy bullets, in quantity, from long ranges which often caused horrific damage on the indigenous peoples. These sights allowed the lobbing of rounds from such long distances. Military rifles almost always have long range sights but these sights on civilian arms are fairly unique to Southern African sporting rifles. An oddity of this tradition of "volley sights on every rifle" carried through to even .22 rifles and .22/.410 combination guns. When I lived in South Africa I observed many .22's with sights to 300, and even 500 yards!
